results.title: Dead letter office
results.creator_credit: John Ruane, Denise Patience, Deb Cox, Steve Vizard, Andrew Knight and Artist Services
results.brief_description: In the dead letter office sit thousands of fading dreams which didn’t reach the recipient because they were insufficiently addressed. One batch of letters are signed by “your bundle of joy”, a young girl named Alice who writes regular letters to her absent father but keeps having them returned with the dead letter office stamp. Alice, now a young woman, begins a job with the dead letter office to continue searching for her father. Once there she encounters a box labelled “special cases”, a sealed collection of letters that the dead letter office doesn’t hold much hope for locating the recipient. Alice is drawn to these scribes like herself and becomes drawn into the misery of others, although her passion for these cases causes conflict amongst the other workers. The office is an odd assortment of employees, headed by manager Frank (George DelHoyo), a political refugee from Chile. Alice and Frank are drawn to each other and after appreciating one another’s dreams and tortured backgrounds, a tentative relationship develops in the most unlikeliest of settings. Cast includes Miranda Otto, George DelHoya, Nicholas Bell, Georgina Naidu, Syd Brisbane and Barry Otto.

results.title: Dead Heart (A) (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Nick Parsons, Helen Watts, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Constable Ray Lorkin (Bryan Brown) struggles to maintain law and order in the Aboriginal community of Wala Wala. The geographical isolation of the community is heightened by the incompatability between “white man’s justice” and indigenous tribal law. The situation reaches crisis point when a young Aboriginal (Aaron Pedersen) allows the white woman with whom he is having an affair to view a sacred initiation site. “Dead Heart” presents an honest portrayal of the conflict between two cultures and laws and the consequences that can occur. Parsons also wrote the script.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick Parsons, Helen Watts, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia

results.title: Dead End Drive-in (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Trenchard-Smith, A Williams, New South Wales Film Corporation and Springvale Productions
results.brief_description: Futuristic satirical comedy which revolves around the use of drive-in theatres as internment camps for outcasts from society where the unemployed and weak are fed junk food, music and bad films. When the film’s main character finds himself there by accident, he is obsessed by a desire to escape and find a new sense of purpose in his life.

results.title: Dead End Drive-In
results.brief_description: In the near future, drive-in theatres are turned into concentration camps for the undesirable and unemployed. The prisoners don’t really care to escape because they are fed and they have a place to live which is, in most cases, probably better than the outside. Crabs and his girlfriend Carmen are put into the camp and all Crabs wants to do is escape.

constellations_other.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_other.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

results.title: Dead end
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the Sidney Kingsley play and scripted for the screen by Lillian Hellman, “Dead end” is one of the most acclaimed crime films. William Wyler directs the young cast of the Dead End Kids in this film which looks at the New York East Side as a breeding ground for potential criminals. Bogart plays gangster “Baby Face Martin”, Joel McCrae is Dave, the student architect trying to break free. America in the Depression is vividly portrayed and while the message of the film is less than subtle, the performances are excellent, as is the script. Co-starring Sylvia Sidney as the sensitive, caring sister of one of the boys.

results.title: Dead easy
results.creator_credit: Bert Deling, John Weiley and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney and supposedly based on actual events, a policeman, prostitute and a hustler become involved in gang war and find that life can be very dangerous. After they cross a small-time bookie they are hunted by every hoodlum in town.

results.title: Dead centre
results.brief_description: There are many kinds of centres: centres of dart boards, baby health centres, fathers who are the centres of their family. There is also the centre of the road: the drivers who stay on it are likely to end up in the dead centre - the Coroner’s Court.

results.title: Dead Calm
results.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 1989
results.brief_description: An Australian couple take a sailing trip in the Pacific to forget about a terrible accident. While on the open sea, in dead calm, they come across a ship with one survivor who is not at all what he seems.

constellations_other.name: 1960s television
constellations_other.description: After its debut in the fifties, Australians rapidly became enthusiastic television viewers in the sixties as American imports started to be mixed with notable local productions.

constellations_other.name: George Miller
constellations_other.description: For a guy who started his career as a physician, George Miller sure is a diverse filmmaker.

results.title: Dead calm
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, George Miller, Doug Mitchell, Terry Hayes, Warner Bros Pictures and Kennedy Miller Productions
results.brief_description: A psychothriller from the novel by Charles Williams about a married couple who have taken time out to recover from a family tragedy by spending time on their yacht at sea. This seemingly idyllic break soon turns into a nightmare when the couple rescue a young man from a drifting boat, unaware of the stranger’s violent and sociopathic personality that is about to set upon them. Stars Sam Neill, Nicole Kidman, Billy Zane. Cinematography by Dean Semler.
